==========
﻿Why Do I Do That?: Psychological Defense Mechanisms and the Hidden Ways They Shape Our Lives (Burgo PhD, Joseph)
- Your Highlight on page 135 | location 2446-2451 | Added on Friday, 18 September 2020 17:40:43

In particular, some men and women seek to control their partners through the very fact of their own helplessness. While they may appear extremely needy and incapable, they often have an unacknowledged fantasy of controlling their partners; they may unconsciously believe that, through their helpless behavior, they are forcing the other person to assume the role of caretaker and that they can manipulate the partner into giving what is wanted, be it emotional or financial support.
==========
﻿Why Do I Do That?: Psychological Defense Mechanisms and the Hidden Ways They Shape Our Lives (Burgo PhD, Joseph)
- Your Highlight on page 135 | location 2445-2453 | Added on Friday, 18 September 2020 17:41:34

While we’ve all known domineering people who actively seek to control others around them, there are other, less recognizable types of control. In particular, some men and women seek to control their partners through the very fact of their own helplessness. While they may appear extremely needy and incapable, they often have an unacknowledged fantasy of controlling their partners; they may unconsciously believe that, through their helpless behavior, they are forcing the other person to assume the role of caretaker and that they can manipulate the partner into giving what is wanted, be it emotional or financial support. In other words, the person who appears extremely needy and helpless often has no more tolerance for actual dependency than the person who tries to control other people; they’re both defending against the awareness of dependency but in different ways, one via active control, the other through an invisible effort to manipulate and thereby gain control. Maybe boundaries between mother and child are confused, and the parent has difficulty bearing separation. A mother may become so mired in anxiety or depression that it limits her ability to meet her baby’s needs, etc. In these cases – somewhere between “good enough” and highly deficient – the damage may be less severe and so will our feelings of shame or internal ugliness; our defenses against that experience won’t dominate our character so pervasively.

Not Nice: Stop People Pleasing, Staying Silent, & Feeling Guilty... And Start Speaking Up, Saying No, Asking Boldly, And Unapologetically Being Yourself (Gazipura, Aziz)

When parents consistently come from a place of frustration, anger, or disapproval, children become subservient and aim to please. The loss of connection and love they feel when a parent is angry with them can be incredibly painful, and becomes a powerful form of influence. Of course, they still act out, do crazy things, and bug the heck out of their parents. But the shift takes place nonetheless, very slowly and subtly over time. Eventually this style of socialization turns politeness into a fear-based sense of following the rules. As children grow up they become scared of doing it wrong, afraid of making mistakes, terrified of being “rude,” and apologizing preemptively for things that are not even apology-worthy.

==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 25 | location 395-399 | Added on Tuesday, 10 November 2020 07:12:25

Achieving a goal only changes your life for the moment. That’s the counterintuitive thing about improvement. We think we need to change our results, but the results are not the problem. What we really need to change are the systems that cause those results. When you solve problems at the results level, you only solve them temporarily. In order to improve for good, you need to solve problems at the systems level. Fix the inputs and the outputs will fix themselves.
==========

Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 26 | location 404-407 | Added on Tuesday, 10 November 2020 07:13:46

Furthermore, goals create an “either-or” conflict: either you achieve your goal and are successful or you fail and you are a disappointment. You mentally box yourself into a narrow version of happiness. This is misguided. It is unlikely that your actual path through life will match the exact journey you had in mind when you set out. It makes no sense to restrict your satisfaction to one scenario when there are many paths to success.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 26 | location 407-410 | Added on Tuesday, 10 November 2020 07:14:04

A systems-first mentality provides the antidote. When you fall in love with the process rather than the product, you don’t have to wait to give yourself permission to be happy. You can be satisfied anytime your system is running. And a system can be successful in many different forms, not just the one you first envision.

At first, these tiny routines seem insignificant, but soon they build on each other and fuel bigger wins that multiply to a degree that far outweighs the cost of their initial investment. They are both small and mighty. This is the meaning of the phrase atomic habits—a regular practice or routine that is not only small and easy to do, but also the source of incredible power; a component of the system of compound growth.

- Your Highlight on page 33 | location 497-499 | Added on Tuesday, 10 November 2020 21:05:04

The ultimate form of intrinsic motivation is when a habit becomes part of your identity. It’s one thing to say I’m the type of person who wants this. It’s something very different to say I’m the type of person who is this.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 33 | location 499-503 | Added on Tuesday, 10 November 2020 21:06:56

The more pride you have in a particular aspect of your identity, the more motivated you will be to maintain the habits associated with it. If you’re proud of how your hair looks, you’ll develop all sorts of habits to care for and maintain it. If you’re proud of the size of your biceps, you’ll make sure you never skip an upper-body workout. If you’re proud of the scarves you knit, you’ll be more likely to spend hours knitting each week. Once your pride gets involved, you’ll fight tooth and nail to maintain your habits.
==========

7.” During the first three trials, the cat escaped in an average of 1.5 minutes. During the last three trials, it escaped in an average of 6.3 seconds. ==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 45 | location 663-664 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:06:36

solutions to recurring problems in our environment.”5

Atomic Habits (Clear, James)

==========

==========

- Your Highlight on page 45 | location 665-667 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:07:09

6 You learn to lock in on the cues that predict success and tune out everything else. When a similar situation arises in the future, you know exactly what to look for. There is no longer a need to analyze every angle of a situation.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 45 | location 665-668 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:07:14

6 You learn to lock in on the cues that predict success and tune out everything else. When a similar situation arises in the future, you know exactly what to look for. There is no longer a need to analyze every angle of a situation. Your brain skips the process of trial and error and creates a mental rule: if this, then that.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 45 | location 668-670 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:08:01

Now, whenever you feel stressed, you get the itch to run. As soon as you walk in the door from work, you grab the video game controller. A choice that once required effort is now automatic. A habit has been created.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 672-673 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:08:54

The primary reason the brain remembers the past is to better predict what will work in the future.7
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 673-674 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:09:21

==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 673-677 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:09:34

Habit formation is incredibly useful because the conscious mind is the bottleneck of the brain.8 It can only pay attention to one problem at a time. As a result, your brain is always working to preserve your conscious attention for whatever task is most essential. Whenever possible, the conscious mind likes to pawn off tasks to the nonconscious mind to do automatically.9
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 677-679 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:09:51

This is precisely what happens when a habit is formed. Habits reduce cognitive load and free up mental capacity, so you can allocate your attention to other tasks.10
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 682-683 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:10:15

Habits do not restrict freedom. They create it. In fact, the people who don’t have their habits handled are often the ones with the least amount of freedom
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 683-685 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:10:30

Without good financial habits, you will always be struggling for the next dollar. Without good health habits, you will always seem to be short on energy. Without good learning habits, you will always feel like you’re behind the curve.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 46 | location 685-688 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:10:48

If you’re always being forced to make decisions about simple tasks—when should I work out, where do I go to write, when do I pay the bills—then you have less time for freedom. It’s only by making the fundamentals of life easier that you can create the mental space needed for free thinking and creativity.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 47 | location 688-690 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:11:15

Conversely, when you have your habits dialed in and the basics of life are handled and done, your mind is free to focus on new challenges and master the next set of problems. Building habits in the present allows you to do more of what you want in the future.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 47 | location 691-693 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:12:39

The process of building a habit can be divided into four simple steps: cue, craving, response, and reward.fn1 Breaking it down into these fundamental parts can help us understand what
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 47 | location 691-693 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:12:58

The process of building a habit can be divided into four simple steps: cue, craving, response, and reward.fn1 Breaking it down into these fundamental parts can help us understand what a habit is, how it works, and how to improve it.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 47 | location 697-698 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:13:17

First, there is the cue. The cue triggers your brain to initiate a behavior. It is a bit of information that predicts a reward.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 701-703 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:13:46

Your mind is continuously analyzing your internal and external environment for hints of where rewards are located. Because the cue is the first indication that we’re close to a reward, it naturally leads to a craving.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 698-699 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:14:14

Our prehistoric ancestors were paying attention to cues that signaled the location of primary rewards like food, water, and sex.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 699-700 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:14:21

Today, we spend most of our time learning cues that predict secondary rewards like money and fame, power and status, praise and approval, love
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 703-704 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:15:11

Cravings are the second step, and they are the motivational force behind every habit. Without some level of motivation or desire—without craving a change—we have no reason to act.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 704-705 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:15:24

What you crave is not the habit itself but the change in state it delivers.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 706-708 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:16:12

Every craving is linked to a desire to change your internal state. This is an important point that we will discuss in detail later.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 708-709 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:17:10

Cravings differ from person to person. In theory, any piece of information could trigger a craving, but in practice, people are not motivated by the same cues. For
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 709-709 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:17:25

a gambler, the sound of slot machines can be a potent trigger that sparks an intense wave of desire.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 709-710 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:18:40

For someone who rarely gambles, the jingles and chimes of the casino are just background noise.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 710-710 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:18:45

Cues are meaningless until they are interpreted.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 711-712 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:19:11

The third step is the response. The response is the actual habit you perform, which can take the form of a thought or an action.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 48 | location 712-713 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:19:23

Whether a response occurs depends on how motivated you are and how much friction is associated with the behavior.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 713-714 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:19:51

If a particular action requires more physical or mental effort than you are willing to expend, then you won’t do it.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 713-716 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:20:10

If a particular action requires more physical or mental effort than you are willing to expend, then you won’t do it. Your response also depends on your ability. It sounds simple, but a habit can occur only if you are capable of doing it. If you want to dunk a basketball but can’t jump high enough to reach the hoop, well, you’re out of luck.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 716-717 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:21:17

Finally, the response delivers a reward. Rewards are the end goal of every habit. The cue is about noticing the reward. The craving is about wanting the reward. The response is about obtaining the reward. We chase rewards because they serve two
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 716-718 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:21:21

Finally, the response delivers a reward. Rewards are the end goal of every habit. The cue is about noticing the reward. The craving is about wanting the reward. The response is about obtaining the reward. We chase rewards because they serve two purposes: (1) they satisfy us and (2) they teach us.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Note on page 49 | location 718 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:22:21

Really key point here
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 718-719 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:22:50

The first purpose of rewards is to satisfy your craving. Yes, rewards provide benefits on their own.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 719-719 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:23:11

==========

- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 720-721 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:23:34

But the more immediate benefit is that rewards satisfy your craving to eat or to gain status or to win approval. At
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 719-721 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:24:19

Food and water deliver the energy you need to survive. Getting a promotion brings more money and respect. Getting in shape improves your health and your dating prospects. But the more immediate benefit is that rewards satisfy your craving to eat or to gain status or to win approval. At
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 721-721 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:25:34

rewards deliver contentment and relief from craving.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 723-725 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:25:50

Feelings of pleasure and disappointment are part of the feedback mechanism that helps your brain distinguish useful actions from useless ones.11 Rewards close the feedback loop and complete the habit cycle.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 49 | location 726-728 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 03:26:24

Eliminate the cue and your habit will never start. Reduce the craving and you won’t experience enough motivation to act. Make the behavior difficult and you won’t be able to do it. And if the reward fails to satisfy your desire, then you’ll have no reason to do it again in the future.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 50 | location 742-743 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 08:18:26

We can split these four steps into two phases: the problem phase and the solution phase. The problem phase includes the cue and the craving, and it is when you realize that something needs to change.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 50 | location 743-744 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 08:18:33

The solution phase includes the response and the reward, and it is when you take action and achieve the change you desire.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 50 | location 750-752 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 08:19:59

By the time we become adults, we rarely notice the habits that are running our lives. Most of us never give a second thought to the fact that we tie the same shoe first each morning, or unplug the toaster after each use, or always change into comfortable clothes after getting home from work.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)

==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 70 | location 942-944 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:23:52

normal rate. The sentence they filled out is what researchers refer to as an implementation intention, which is a plan you make beforehand about when and where to act. That is, how you intend to implement a particular habit. The cues that
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 70 | location 942-945 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:24:06

normal rate. The sentence they filled out is what researchers refer to as an implementation intention, which is a plan you make beforehand about when and where to act. That is, how you intend to implement a particular habit. The cues that can trigger a habit come in a wide range of forms—the feel of your phone buzzing in your pocket, the smell of chocolate chip cookies, the sound of ambulance sirens—but the two most common cues are time and location.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 70 | location 947-948 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:24:16

an implementation intention is: “When situation X arises, I will perform response Y.”
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 70 | location 957-960 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:25:21

The punch line is clear: people who make a specific plan for when and where they will perform a new habit are more likely to follow through.7 Too many people try to change their habits without these basic details figured out. We tell ourselves, “I’m going to eat healthier” or “I’m going to write more,” but we never say when and where these habits are going to happen.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 71 | location 967-969 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:26:00

The simple way to apply this strategy to your habits is to fill out this sentence: I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 72 | location 977-978 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:26:46

Being specific about what you want and how you will achieve it helps you say no to things that derail progress, distract your attention, and pull you off course.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 72 | location 978-979 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:26:55

We often say yes to little requests because we are not clear enough about what we need to be doing instead.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 72 | location 979-980 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:28:52

When your dreams are vague, it’s easy to rationalize little exceptions all day long and never get around to the specific things you need to do to succeed.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 72 | location 982-984 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:29:12

never going to just work out without conscious thought.9 But like a dog salivating at a bell, maybe you start to get antsy around the time of day you normally work out.”
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 73 | location 1000-1001 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:31:46

purchase led to the next. Diderot’s behavior is not uncommon. In fact, the tendency for one purchase to lead to another one has a name: the Diderot Effect.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 73 | location 1000-1003 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:31:57

purchase led to the next. Diderot’s behavior is not uncommon. In fact, the tendency for one purchase to lead to another one has a name: the Diderot Effect. The Diderot Effect states that obtaining a new possession often creates a spiral of consumption that leads to additional purchases.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 74 | location 1009-1011 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:32:57

the connectedness of behavior to your advantage. One of the best ways to build a new habit is to identify a current habit you already do each day and then stack your new behavior on top. This is called habit stacking.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 74 | location 1012-1012 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:33:04

Rather than pairing your new habit with a particular time and location, you pair it with a current habit.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 74 | location 1024-1026 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:34:27

The key is to tie your desired behavior into something you already do each day. Once you have mastered this basic structure, you can begin to create larger stacks by chaining small habits together. This allows you to take advantage of the natural momentum that comes from one behavior leading into the next—a positive version of the Diderot Effect.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1041-1042 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:35:33

Overall, habit stacking allows you to create a set of simple rules that guide your future behavior.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1042-1044 | Added on Thursday, 12 November 2020 22:35:49

Once you get comfortable with this approach, you can develop general habit stacks to guide you whenever the situation is appropriate:
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1087-1088 | Added on Saturday, 14 November 2020 10:50:12

“When I close my laptop for lunch, I will do ten push-ups next to my desk.” Ambiguity gone.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1088-1090 | Added on Saturday, 14 November 2020 10:50:23

Habits like “read more” or “eat better” are worthy causes, but these goals do not provide instruction on how and when to act. Be specific and clear: After I close the door. After I brush my teeth. After I sit down at the table. The specificity is important.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1090-1091 | Added on Saturday, 14 November 2020 10:50:51

The more tightly bound your new habit is to a specific cue, the better the odds are that you will notice when the time comes to act.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1091-1092 | Added on Saturday, 14 November 2020 10:51:02

The 1st Law of Behavior Change is to make it obvious. Strategies like implementation intentions and habit stacking are among the most practical ways to create obvious cues for your habits and design a clear plan for when and where to take action.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1098-1099 | Added on Saturday, 14 November 2020 10:52:35

I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)

I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION]. ■ Habit stacking is a strategy you can use to pair a new habit with a current habit. ■ The habit stacking formula is: After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 81 | location 1106-1107 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:33:28

Thorndike and her colleagues designed a six-month study to alter the “choice architecture” of the hospital cafeteria.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 81 | location 1110-1112 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:34:22

Over the next three months, the number of soda sales at the hospital dropped by 11.4 percent. Meanwhile, sales of bottled water increased by 25.8 percent. They made similar adjustments—and saw similar results—with the food in the cafeteria. Nobody had said a word to anyone eating there.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1121-1123 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:40:16

If the communal table at the office is always filled with doughnuts and bagels, it’s going to be hard not to grab one every now and then. Your habits change depending on the room you are in and the cues in front of you.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1125-1126 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:40:32

In this way, the most common form of change is not internal, but external: we are changed by the world around us. Every habit is context dependent.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1126-1128 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:40:57

In 1936, psychologist Kurt Lewin wrote a simple equation that makes a powerful statement: Behavior is a function of the Person in their Environment, or B = f (P,E).3 It didn’t
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1128-1130 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:41:03

take long for Lewin’s Equation to be tested in business. In 1952, the economist Hawkins Stern described a phenomenon he called Suggestion Impulse Buying, which “is triggered when a shopper sees a product for the first time and visualizes a need for it.”
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1147-1149 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:47:50

The most powerful of all human sensory abilities, however, is vision. The human body has about eleven million sensory receptors.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1149-1150 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:47:57

Approximately ten million of those are dedicated to sight. Some experts estimate that half of the brain’s resources are used on vision.8
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1150-1151 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:48:02

Given that we are more dependent on vision than on any other sense, it should come as no surprise that visual cues are the greatest catalyst of our behavior.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1153-1155 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:48:21

Thankfully, there is good news in this respect. You don’t have to be the victim of your environment. You can also be the architect of it.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1162-1162 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:48:54

Every habit is initiated by a cue, and we are more likely to notice cues that stand out.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1164-1165 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:49:04

not to practice the guitar when it’s tucked away in the closet. It’s easy not to read a book when the bookshelf is in the corner of the guest room.

- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1165-1166 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:49:08

==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1168-1170 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:53:30

The stickers improved their aim and significantly reduced “spillage” around the urinals. Further analysis determined that the stickers cut bathroom cleaning costs by 8 percent per year.

- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1177-1179 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:54:34

Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1182-1183 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:54:44

==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1186-1186 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:57:08

By sprinkling triggers throughout your surroundings, you increase the odds that you’ll think about your habit throughout the day.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1188-1189 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:58:37

Environment design is powerful not only because it influences how we engage with the world but also because we rarely do it.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1189-1190 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:58:45

Most people live in a world others have created for them. But you can alter the spaces where you live and work to increase your exposure to positive cues and reduce your exposure to negative ones.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1190-1192 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 08:58:53

Environment design allows you to take back control and become the architect of your life. Be the designer of your world and not merely the consumer of it.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1194-1196 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:00:58

surrounding the behavior. For example, many people drink more in social situations than they would ever drink alone. The trigger is rarely a single cue, but rather the whole situation: watching your friends order drinks, hearing the music at the bar, seeing the beers on tap.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1197-1198 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:01:10

You establish a particular relationship with the objects on your desk, the items on your kitchen counter, the things in your bedroom.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1198-1199 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:01:18

Our behavior is not defined by the objects in the environment but by our relationship to them.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1200-1201 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:01:26

Start thinking about it as filled with relationships. Think in terms of how you interact with the spaces around you.

Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1206-1208 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:02:14

Their brains learned that sleeping—not browsing on their phones, not watching television, not staring at the clock—was the only action that happened in that room.11
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1204-1205 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:03:02

In one study, scientists instructed insomniacs to get into bed only when they were tired. If they couldn’t fall asleep, they were told to sit in a different room until they became sleepy.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1208-1211 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:04:27

The power of context also reveals an important strategy: habits can be easier to change in a new environment.12 It helps to escape the subtle triggers and cues that nudge you toward your current habits. Go to a new place—a different coffee shop, a bench in the park, a corner of your room you seldom use—and create a new routine there.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1213-1216 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:04:55

But when you step outside your normal environment, you leave your behavioral biases behind.13 You aren’t battling old environmental cues, which allows new habits to form without interruption.14
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1216-1218 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:05:06

Want to think more creatively? Move to a bigger room, a rooftop patio, or a building with expansive architecture. Take a break from the space where you do your daily work, which is also linked to your current thought patterns.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 89 | location 1221-1222 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:05:38

Create a separate space for work, study, exercise, entertainment, and cooking. The mantra I find useful is “One space, one use.”
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 89 | location 1222-1225 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:16:09

When I started my career as an entrepreneur, I would often work from my couch or at the kitchen table. In the evenings, I found it very difficult to stop working. There was no clear division between the end of work time and the beginning of personal time. Was the kitchen table my office or the space where I ate meals? Was the couch where I relaxed or where I sent emails? Everything happened in the same place.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 89 | location 1222-1228 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:16:36

When I started my career as an entrepreneur, I would often work from my couch or at the kitchen table. In the evenings, I found it very difficult to stop working. There was no clear division between the end of work time and the beginning of personal time. Was the kitchen table my office or the space where I ate meals? Was the couch where I relaxed or where I sent emails? Everything happened in the same place. A few years later, I could finally afford to move to a home with a separate room for my office. Suddenly, work was something that happened “in here” and personal life was something that happened “out there.” It was easier for me to turn off the professional side of my brain when there was a clear dividing line between work life and home life. Each room had one primary use. The
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 89 | location 1222-1228 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:16:39

When I started my career as an entrepreneur, I would often work from my couch or at the kitchen table. In the evenings, I found it very difficult to stop working. There was no clear division between the end of work time and the beginning of personal time. Was the kitchen table my office or the space where I ate meals? Was the couch where I relaxed or where I sent emails? Everything happened in the same place. A few years later, I could finally afford to move to a home with a separate room for my office. Suddenly, work was something that happened “in here” and personal life was something that happened “out there.” It was easier for me to turn off the professional side of my brain when there was a clear dividing line between work life and home life. Each room had one primary use. The kitchen was for cooking. The office was for working.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 90 | location 1234-1235 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:17:11

Fair enough. If your space is limited, divide your room into activity zones: a chair for reading, a desk for writing, a table for eating.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 90 | location 1235-1237 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:17:24

know a writer who uses his computer only for writing, his tablet only for reading, and his phone only for social media and texting. Every habit should have a home.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 90 | location 1239-1240 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:17:40

Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 91 | location 1257-1260 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:18:59

Lee Robins was one of the researchers in charge. In a finding that completely upended the accepted beliefs about addiction, Robins found that when soldiers who had been heroin users returned home, only 5 percent of them became re-addicted within a year, and just 12 percent relapsed within three years. In other words, approximately nine out of ten soldiers who used heroin in Vietnam
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 91 | location 1257-1261 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:19:03

Lee Robins was one of the researchers in charge. In a finding that completely upended the accepted beliefs about addiction, Robins found that when soldiers who had been heroin users returned home, only 5 percent of them became re-addicted within a year, and just 12 percent relapsed within three years. In other words, approximately nine out of ten soldiers who used heroin in Vietnam eliminated their addiction nearly overnight.3
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1261-1263 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:19:45

This finding contradicted the prevailing view at the time, which considered heroin addiction to be a permanent and irreversible condition. Instead, Robins revealed that addictions could spontaneously dissolve if there was a radical change in the environment.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1265-1266 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:19:57

Once a soldier returned to the United States, though, he found himself in an environment devoid of those triggers. When the context changed, so did the habit.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1269-1270 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:21:02

Typically, 90 percent of heroin users become re-addicted once they return home from rehab.4
==========

- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1269-1273 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:21:25

Typically, 90 percent of heroin users become re-addicted once they return home from rehab.4 The Vietnam studies ran counter to many of our cultural beliefs about bad habits because it challenged the conventional association of unhealthy behavior as a moral weakness. If you’re overweight, a smoker, or an addict, you’ve been told your entire life that it is because you lack self-control—maybe even that you’re a bad person. The idea that a little bit of discipline would solve all

- Your Highlight on page 93 | location 1293-1296 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:31:40

Worrying about your health makes you feel anxious, which causes you to smoke to ease your anxiety, which makes your health even worse and soon you’re feeling more anxious. It’s a downward spiral, a runaway train of bad habits. Researchers refer to this phenomenon
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 93 | location 1293-1296 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:32:03

Worrying about your health makes you feel anxious, which causes you to smoke to ease your anxiety, which makes your health even worse and soon you’re feeling more anxious. It’s a downward spiral, a runaway train of bad habits. Researchers refer to this phenomenon as “cue-induced wanting”: an external trigger causes a compulsive craving to repeat a bad habit.
==========
Atomic Habits (Clear, James)
- Your Highlight on page 94 | location 1299-1300 | Added on Sunday, 15 November 2020 09:32:20

This speed is too fast for the brain to consciously register—the addicts couldn’t even tell you what they had seen—but they craved the drug all the same.
==========

we become a product of the environment that we live in. To put it bluntly, I have never seen someone consistently stick to positive habits in a negative environment.

There was so much emotion attached to the events that took place, and these memories haunted me for a very long time.
==========
Good Vibes, Good Life (King, Vex)
- Your Highlight on page xiv | location 132-133 | Added on Tuesday, 17 November 2020 20:47:24

felt uncomfortable with who I was.
==========
Good Vibes, Good Life (King, Vex)
- Your Highlight on page xiv | location 131-134 | Added on Tuesday, 17 November 2020 20:47:30

During my late teens, I wished a lot of these memories would just go away. I wanted to erase them so that I was no longer reminded of the struggles I’d faced as a child. I was even embarrassed by some of them. I felt uncomfortable with who I was. There were times when I said and did things that didn’t match the child I was deep down. I often felt hurt by the world – and wanted to hurt it back.
==========
Good Vibes, Good Life (King, Vex)
- Your Highlight on page xv | location 136-137 | Added on Tuesday, 17 November 2020 20:47:37

realize that the good, the bad and the downright ugly events are all a part of who I’ve become.
==========

Although some of them may have been painful, they’re a blessing – they’ve taught me so much.

==========

demand, challenge, and discomfort are the forces that cause us to grow and become our fullest, most powerful selves. In fact, they’re the very signs that we are developing. They’re essential, healthy, and necessary. Not to mention that Candace is incredibly strong and resilient. She works through challenging and uncomfortable feelings and lets them go more rapidly than anyone I’ve met. These rules are not coming from our rational, adult minds. They’re coming from deep within our emotional brain that recorded hundreds of lessons from our years of Nice Training. Lessons that your parents consciously taught you, and lessons that you learned just by being an observant, intelligent child. Mom gets mad when I resist her and say no; therefore, saying no is bad. Dad gets upset when I disagree with him; therefore, disagreeing with others is bad. Many of these rules are not even things you would agree with if you slowed down and examined then consciously. ==========
Not Nice: Stop People Pleasing, Staying Silent, & Feeling Guilty... And Start Speaking Up, Saying No, Asking Boldly, And Unapologetically Being Yourself (Gazipura, Aziz)
- Your Highlight on page 64 | location 906-914 | Added on Saturday, 21 November 2020 19:31:22

demand, challenge, and discomfort are the forces that cause us to grow and become our fullest, most powerful selves. In fact, they’re the very signs that we are developing. They’re essential, healthy, and necessary. Not to mention that Candace is incredibly strong and resilient. She works through challenging and uncomfortable feelings and lets them go more rapidly than anyone I’ve met. These rules are not coming from our rational, adult minds. They’re coming from deep within our emotional brain that recorded hundreds of lessons from our years of Nice Training. Lessons that your parents consciously taught you, and lessons that you learned just by being an observant, intelligent child. Mom gets mad when I resist her and say no; therefore, saying no is bad. Dad gets upset when I disagree with him; therefore, disagreeing with others is bad. Many of these rules are not even things you would agree with if you slowed down and examined then consciously. They’re just old programs you picked up long ago that continue to guide your feelings and behavior, regardless of whether you believe them.
==========
Not Nice: Stop People Pleasing, Staying Silent, & Feeling Guilty... And Start Speaking Up, Saying No, Asking Boldly, And Unapologetically Being Yourself (Gazipura, Aziz)
- Your Highlight on page 65 | location 915-917 | Added on Saturday, 21 November 2020 19:31:44

- Your Highlight on page 57 | location 867-868 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:40:31

However, we can also anticipate in negative ways, expecting and imagining negative or even dangerous
==========

- Your Highlight on page 57 | location 868-868 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:40:38

events. This can lead to a great deal of distress.

- Your Highlight on page 58 | location 885-886 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:44:25

In fact, she’s been the victim of a variety of crimes, probably because she lacks the caution that would arise from a functioning amygdala.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 59 | location 887-888 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:44:40

No matter what thoughts, images, or expectations originate in the cortex, many of the emotional and physiological aspects of anxiety result only when the cortex activates the amygdala.

In reacting to the cortex’s information, the amygdala may initiate the fight, flight, or freeze response. And once the amygdala gets involved, you begin to experience the physical sensations associated with anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 916-918 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:52:51

The first step is to recognize when the cortex is producing thoughts or images that may lead to anxiety. When you become aware of these thoughts and their anxiety-inducing effects, you can begin to recognize the thoughts, identify when they occur, and take steps to change them.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 62 | location 924-925 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:53:21

This is a key step in determining how to rewire your brain to control your anxiety. Once you identify the starting point of your anxiety, you can apply the right techniques to effectively address the problem.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 63 | location 934-937 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:54:35

If you become anxious when you see a growling dog and begin to hyperventilate, that would be amygdala-initiated anxiety. If you’re pacing nervously as you anticipate an important phone call, that would be cortex-initiated anxiety. Understanding where and how your anxiety begins will allow you to take the most effective approach to interrupting the process.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 64 | location 937-939 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:54:53

It’s important to remember that when anxiety begins in the amygdala, cortex-based interventions, such as logic and reasoning, don’t always help reduce anxiety. Amygdala-based anxiety can often be identified by certain characteristics; for example, it seems to come from out of the blue, it creates strong physiological responses, and it seems out of proportion to the situation.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 65 | location 956-958 | Added on Saturday, 27 February 2021 22:58:44

As explained in chapter 3, the left hemisphere of the cortex can produce a type of anxious apprehension that shows up as a tendency to worry about what will happen and search repetitively for solutions. With this type of anxiety, people tend to ruminate or focus intensely on a situation or feel the need to discuss a situation repeatedly.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 66 | location 968-969 | Added on Sunday, 28 February 2021 22:01:55

to mind thoughts that increase your level of anxiety. Although your left hemisphere may be looking for a solution, a strong focus on potential difficulties can activate the amygdala.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 66 | location 972-972 | Added on Sunday, 28 February 2021 22:02:11

==========

Cortex-based strategies for coping with anxiety are often not very useful when the amygdala is activated. Some of the strategies discussed in part 2 of the book, such as deep breathing or relaxation, will be helpful even when your thought processes are limited by activation of the amygdala.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1119-1119 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 07:57:39

In all cases, these extreme responses are caused by activation of the fight, flight, or freeze response when it isn’t necessary.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1134-1138 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 07:58:47

In the second half of the chapter, you assessed whether you’re prone to experiences of amygdala-based anxiety: unexplained anxiety, rapid physiological responding, unplanned aggressive feelings or behavior, inability to think clearly, and extreme responses. Now that you have a better idea of where your anxiety originates—in your cortex, amygdala, or both—you’re ready to look more closely at the nature of each type of anxiety and learn techniques that will help you minimize or control your specific anxiety responses.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1152-1154 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 07:59:36

The fight, flight, or freeze pattern of responding was first recognized by physiologist Walter Cannon (1929). Then, in the 1930s, endocrinologist Hans Selye recognized that animals and humans alike have a surprisingly similar reaction to a broad set of stressors.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1162-1164 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:00:30

Whether we’re being chased by a bear, being asked to dance at a party, or being fired from a job, our bodies react in a way that’s surprisingly similar to how the body of a rat being chased with a broom reacts.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1167-1168 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:01:32

All of these changes result from activation of the sympathetic nervous system and the release of stress hormones, such as cortisol and adrenaline.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1171-1173 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:02:55

Now, add to this response the fact that the amygdala is capable of identifying a situation as dangerous in just a fraction of a second, before the rest of the brain even knows exactly what the situation is. Other types of processing, such as perception, thinking, and retrieving memories from the cortex, may take more than a second to occur.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1177-1179 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:03:17

In order to operate quickly and automatically enough to be effective, the stress response cannot be based on the higher-level thinking processes we humans are so proud of possessing. It must operate more quickly than cortex-based circuitry would allow—if not, it may be too late!
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1190-1191 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:03:53

But in reality, the symptoms they’re experiencing are completely normal and simply mean the amygdala has been activated.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1193-1196 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:04:07

They won’t be helpful if you receive an overdue notice on your mortgage payment or your teenage daughter starts arguing with you. But these physiological reactions are hardwired into you, and once the central nucleus activates them, you’ll have to contend with them.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1199-1200 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:04:33

One of the most important parts of the brain it’s connected to is the hypothalamus, a peanut-sized region of the brain that controls a variety of bodily processes, including
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1203-1205 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:04:59

The brain is organized in such a way that the processing in the amygdala pathway occurs in milliseconds. Many studies conducted on rats and mice, which share this same stress response system, have greatly increased our understanding of these amygdala processes (LeDoux 1996).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1207-1208 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:05:14

We know it can be discouraging to learn that your clearest thinking skills and personal insights are essentially disabled by ancient brain structures that create fear-related responses.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1210-1211 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:05:32

The key is to realize that many cortex-based coping strategies, such as telling yourself to stop being afraid or that there’s no logical reason to be anxious, won’t stop the activation of the stress response once it’s initiated.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1217-1220 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:09:55

Other possible symptoms include sympathetic nervous system reactions such as light-headedness, nausea, numbness or tingling, tightness in the chest, a sensation of being smothered, difficulty swallowing, or hot flushes or chills. In addition, the pupils dilate, making the world seem unnaturally bright, and time may seem to pass more slowly.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1235-1235 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:11:23

Agoraphobia has the potential to confine people to their home,
==========

- Your Highlight on page 90 | location 1273-1275 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 08:13:27

If you leave the situation, your amygdala will learn to escape the situation rather than learning that the situation is safe. This point can’t be overemphasized, and we’ll return to it in chapter 8.
==========

==========

- Your Highlight on page 91 | location 1298-1299 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 19:55:58

The good news is, it always passes. If others are present, the best way for them to help is to remind you to breathe deeply and relax your muscles,
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)

which will be naturally tensing and tightening as your
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1311-1313 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 19:57:28

Doing so requires diverting the flow of information leaving the lateral nucleus of the amygdala. Rather than traveling to the central nucleus, information from the lateral nucleus is instead sent to the basal nucleus of the amygdala, which promotes active responses.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 92 | location 1315-1320 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 19:58:07

Initially, it’s important to just do something—anything at all. You may not feel capable of doing complicated or demanding tasks, but don’t allow yourself to freeze and become immobilized, like a frightened rabbit, because this will strengthen the wiring that underlies passive responding. Find something active you can do, even if it’s just calling someone on the phone. In fact, social activities that involve enjoyable interactions with others, or simple pleasurable activities that distract you from your worries, can keep your amygdala from creating responses characterized by freezing, avoidance, and immobilization.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 94 | location 1323-1324 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:02:42

She was shifting her amygdala to a more active response, making her less likely to engage in avoidant behavior for the rest of the day.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 95 | location 1340-1340 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:04:13

First, as we’ve noted, the cortex doesn’t have many direct connections to the amygdala. Second,
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 95 | location 1340-1341 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:04:19

the initiator of the stress response is the amygdala. Therefore, interventions that target the amygdala are more direct and effective in easing anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 95 | location 1344-1346 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:05:02

These spontaneously activated processes, whether described as anxiety, the stress response, or the fight, flight, or freeze response, result from brain activities that don’t lie within conscious awareness.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 96 | location 1354-1355 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:06:54

When you reduce amygdala activation, you reduce SNS responding, and with practice, the PNS can be trained to intervene.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 96 | location 1357-1359 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:07:22

Recent neuroimaging studies have identified actual changes in the brain that occur when people practice various relaxation techniques, including meditation (Desbordes et al. 2012), chanting (Kalyani et al. 2011), yoga (Froeliger et al. 2012), and breathing exercises (Goldin and Gross 2010).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 97 | location 1366-1367 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:07:54

Relaxation is also an integral component of more complex approaches to reducing stress and anxiety, such as meditation and yoga.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 98 | location 1387-1388 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:14:40

This can cause dizziness, belching, a feeling of unreality or confusion, or feelings of tingling in the hands, feet, or face.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 98 | location 1385-1388 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:14:45

When people are anxious, they’re likely to breathe quickly and shallowly. They may not get enough oxygen, which produces an uncomfortable sensation. Hyperventilation can also result, due to expelling carbon dioxide too quickly, resulting in low levels of carbon dioxide in the blood. This can cause dizziness, belching, a feeling of unreality or confusion, or feelings of tingling in the hands, feet, or face.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 98 | location 1389-1389 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:15:08

Correcting this imbalance using deliberate breathing techniques sends a signal to the amygdala to relax.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 99 | location 1391-1394 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:15:35

People who are hyperventilating are often instructed to deliberately slow their breathing or breathe into a paper bag. The bag captures carbon dioxide when they exhale; therefore, breathing in from the bag increases the amount of carbon dioxide inhaled and replaced in the bloodstream. It’s a very effective method of reversing light-headedness and other anxiety symptoms.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 100 | location 1407-1408 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:16:38

Also try to notice times when you’re holding your breath, breathing shallowly, or hyperventilating, and then make a deliberate effort to adopt a better breathing pattern.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 100 | location 1408-1409 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:16:57

Breathing is an essential bodily response that you can control, and in the process, you can
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 101 | location 1418-1420 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:22:25

Constant muscle tension uses energy and can leave people feeling tight and exhausted at the end of the day. The first step in reducing muscle tension is to discover which areas of your body tend to tighten up when you’re anxious. The next exercise will help you do just that.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 101 | location 1432-1433 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:26:58

Often, tensing and releasing muscles helps create a feeling of relaxation in those muscles.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 105 | location 1483-1485 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:31:00

Either way, the most important goal is to achieve deep breathing and relaxed muscles. That’s the key to reducing activation of the amygdala. The truth is, it doesn’t matter whether you attain this state by directly focusing on your breathing and muscles or by imagining
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 105 | location 1485-1486 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:31:05

yourself in a setting that allows you to relax.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 108 | location 1536-1539 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:33:00

Those who had engaged in breath-focused meditation had less amygdala activation in response to the statements. In another study (Desbordes et al. 2012), adults without an anxiety disorder were trained in breath-focused or compassion-focused meditation. All experienced a general and lasting decrease in amygdala activation, with those who were trained in breath-focused meditation experiencing greater benefits.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 108 | location 1544-1546 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:34:15

One study (Jerath et al. 2012) found that after meditation, people have a slower breathing rate and increased PNS activation. These effects are probably central to its effectiveness. The next exercise will help you enjoy the benefits of reducing activation of the amygdala through a focus on breathing.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 112 | location 1576-1578 | Added on Monday, 1 March 2021 20:34:55

The ultimate goal is to increase activation of your PNS to help you recover from the stress response and promote well-being. Slower breathing and relaxed muscles will send a message directly to the amygdala that the body is calming down, which is more likely to calm the amygdala than all of the thinking you can do.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 114 | location 1602-1604 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:02:58

For Don, the soap was associated with negative events, so he had a negative reaction to it. For Don’s wife, however, the soap was neutral because her amygdala hadn’t created any emotional memories about it. Therefore, the soap doesn’t trigger any reaction in her.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 116 | location 1628-1630 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:06:39

Afterward, whenever the amygdala hears a car horn, it produces a fear reaction. It’s important to bear in mind that the horn didn’t cause the accident; it’s just associated with the accident.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 116 | location 1630-1631 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:06:45

Remember, the language of the amygdala is based on associations or pairings, not cause and effect.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 117 | location 1642-1643 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:20:38

Both the trigger and the negative event are stimuli, meaning they’re objects, events, or situations that you see, hear, feel, smell, or experience.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 117 | location 1643-1645 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:21:30

The trigger differs from the negative event because you learn to fear or be anxious about the trigger, whereas the negative event is something you don’t have to learn to react to.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 117 | location 1646-1647 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:22:24

Learned fear responses can occur with a variety of objects, sounds, or situations, as long as they’re associated in time with a strong negative event.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 117 | location 1647-1648 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:22:31

Feeling motion sickness on a roller coaster can cause someone to be fearful of amusement park rides. On the other hand, a different person might feel excited on the same ride and love the roller coaster as a result.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 123 | location 1742-1744 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:34:22

For example, a postal carrier who works in a residential neighborhood and has a fear of dogs may very well want to choose to work on that fear first, since that trigger shows up multiple times on every single workday.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 124 | location 1747-1750 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:34:45

Rather, choose to target triggers in those situations in which your anxiety stands in the way of your personal goals and dreams, those that result in the greatest distress, or those you encounter most frequently. In general, the best way to start is with a situation in which reducing your anxiety would significantly improve your life. In the next chapter, we’ll show you how to rewire your amygdala to accomplish this.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 125 | location 1754-1755 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:36:58

To get the amygdala to create these new connections, you need to expose it to situations that contradict the association between a trigger and negative event.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 125 | location 1755-1757 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:37:08

If you show the amygdala new information that’s inconsistent with what it’s previously experienced, it will make new connections in response to this information and learn from the new experience.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 125 | location 1758-1760 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:37:33

It’s similar to adding a bypass of a well-traveled area on a highway. When you create a new neural path and practice traveling it again and again, you establish an alternate route that avoids trouble. Responding with fear and anxiety is no longer your only option. You can establish other, calmer responses as a way around your anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Bookmark on page 126 | location 1767 | Added on Tuesday, 2 March 2021 23:42:45


==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 127 | location 1783-1785 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 08:50:52

Systematic desensitization and flooding are two examples of exposure-based treatment. Systematic desensitization involves learning relaxation strategies and approaching feared objects or situations in a gradual manner. Typically,
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 127 | location 1786-1788 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 08:54:11

With flooding, in contrast, people jump right in with the most fear-provoking situation, and the exposure may last for hours. Flooding is a more intense approach, but it also provides relief from anxiety much more quickly.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 127 | location 1788-1792 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 08:54:33

With either approach, in most cases people initially confront feared situations mentally, by imagining themselves in the feared situation. But ultimately, they must directly experience the situation, usually repeatedly. Obviously, this is a challenging form of treatment, but research shows that it’s exactly the approach needed to rewire the amygdala (Amano, Unal, and Paré 2010). Therefore, the more you practice exposure, the more likely it is that your amygdala will respond calmly to previously feared situations and triggers.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 128 | location 1803-1804 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 08:58:10

Knowing that this process is required to rewire your brain will help you rise to the challenges and make the stress of the experience more tolerable.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 129 | location 1811-1813 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 08:58:48

Again, you must activate the neurons to generate these connections. You must experience fear or anxiety in order to conquer it. There’s more than cowboy wisdom in the old adage “You gotta get back on the horse that threw you.”
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 129 | location 1824-1825 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:01:03

To remind yourself why it’s necessary to experience anxiety, remember the phrase “activate to generate.”
==========

- Your Highlight on page 130 | location 1827-1829 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:01:23

In fact, evidence shows that people who have higher levels of emotional arousal benefit most from exposure during initial exposure experiences (Cahill, Franklin, and Feeny 2006).
==========

- Your Highlight on page 130 | location 1829-1831 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:01:48

Animal research and brain imaging indicate that exposure, the process of experiencing a situation or object that causes anxiety while nothing negative happens, allows another portion of the brain to exert some control over how the amygdala responds
==========

- Your Highlight on page 130 | location 1833-1834 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:02:04

During exposure, learning occurs in the amygdala, and the memory of this learning is stored by the ventral medial prefrontal cortex.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 130 | location 1834-1835 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:02:13

The fear learned in and stored by the amygdala isn’t erased (Phelps 2009), but other circuitry is developed, and new, calmer responses are learned.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 130 | location 1837-1839 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:04:56

In a similar way, your neural circuits need to be activated (or hot) to make new connections. When it comes to anxiety, you need to be exposed to the heat if you want to rewire your neural circuitry.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1842-1843 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:05:38

If we want to help him create new circuitry and change his fear of cats, we need to expose him to friendly cats in order to retrain his amygdala.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1845-1846 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:05:58

The more the child observes or interacts with cats in the absence of negative events, the stronger the new neutral or positive connections will become and the less anxiety he’ll experience.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1846-1847 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:06:01

With repeated exposure to friendly cats, the child’s amygdala will create a bypass around his fear and anxiety.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1848-1849 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:06:21

There’s no way to change the circuitry the lateral nucleus has created without giving the amygdala new experiences with a cat and, as a consequence, creating some anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1849-1850 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:06:27

In fact, the child’s anxiety is a good indication that the correct circuits in the amygdala have been activated and are ready for new learning.
==========
