- Your Highlight on page 131 | location 1853-1856 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:07:10

providing a route around the anxiety response. The more the child is exposed to positive experiences with cats, the stronger the path will become and the more likely it is that the child will feel positive emotions, rather than anxiety, when he encounters cats in the future. Repeated exposure creates this new, alternative response.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 132 | location 1859-1860 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:07:27

The optimal condition for learning to take place in the amygdala is when the neurons are excited, just as the optimal condition for building muscle mass in the body is when the muscle fibers are fatigued.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 132 | location 1860-1862 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:07:45

In a parallel way, as you do more repetitions, you grow stronger. You can think of exposure as a way of providing exercises that will train your amygdala.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 132 | location 1862-1863 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:07:55

We assure you that a great deal of evidence indicates that exposure is a highly effective way of changing the connections in the brain that are responsible for anxiety.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 132 | location 1864-1865 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:08:10

You shouldn’t try exposure until you’re confident you’ll follow through, because it’s possible to actually strengthen anxiety if you leave the exposure situation before your anxiety decreases.
==========

==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 135 | location 1898-1900 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:09:49

Remember, courage is not the absence of fear; courage is acting despite fear. The more you experience anxiety and stay in the situation long enough for your fear to diminish, the stronger the new circuitry will become.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 135 | location 1906-1911 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:10:11

Once you’ve selected the situation you want to focus on, decide whether you prefer the slow, systematic desensitization approach or want to plunge right in with flooding. In the systematic desensitization approach, you’ll take the process step-by-step in a gradual way, working your way up to the most challenging situations over time. In the flooding approach, you’ll begin with some of the most challenging situations and work through them in an intense process. Again, flooding is quicker, but either approach will work. In this chapter, we’ll guide you through the systematic desensitization approach, helping you break down the process into a hierarchy of steps. However, you can easily use flooding by simply starting with some of the most difficult situations.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 136 | location 1925-1926 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:10:24

Next, we ask her to order these behaviors from least to most anxiety provoking, placing them between the first two extremes she identified.

and light-headedness. These might include interoceptive
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 138 | location 1939-1943 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:12:23

If you have obsessive-compulsive disorder, an exposure hierarchy can also help you learn to resist compulsions. You simply create a similar hierarchy of situations that provoke compulsive behaviors and then expose yourself to those situations without allowing yourself to perform compulsions in response. So if touching canned goods results in a compulsion to wash your hands, you’d touch canned goods repeatedly without washing your hands. This process is called exposure with response prevention.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 138 | location 1944-1947 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:12:58

We recommend using deep breathing and other relaxation techniques from chapter 6 to cope with the anxiety you feel during each session. You need not experience a high level of anxiety for rewiring of the circuits to occur, but if anxiety is high during exposure, this can speed the process of change (Cahill, Franklin, and Feeny 2006).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 138 | location 1949-1950 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:13:22

In other words, if you rate your initial anxiety in a situation at 80 on a scale of 1 to 100, don’t leave the situation until your anxiety diminishes to 40 or below.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 139 | location 1950-1952 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:13:37

Your amygdala needs to learn that it’s safe and that escape isn’t necessary. Remember, this is something you must show the amygdala; it only learns through experience.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 139 | location 1956-1958 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:13:58

If you don’t schedule your exposures and plan to repeat them, you won’t rewire your brain and reduce your anxiety. Finally, we recommend that you reward yourself for your progress each time you surmount a step. You deserve a reward for putting yourself through these difficult exercises!
==========

When you detect self-defeating or anxiety-provoking thoughts, try to substitute helpful coping thoughts, such as these:

Just like having toned abdominal muscles requires doing a lot of sit-ups, changing fear responses requires that you face feared situations and conquer them one step at a time.
==========

Exercise has surprisingly powerful effects on the amygdala, surpassing many antianxiety medications in effectiveness.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 143 | location 1995-1997 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:17:32

Instead of resisting your body’s preparations to fight or flee, why not look for opportunities to work with that instinct and utilize your muscles in ways that will decrease the amygdala’s activation?
==========

- Your Highlight on page 144 | location 1998-1999 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:17:42

If you run or walk briskly when you feel anxious, you’ll make use of muscles that have been prepared for action.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 144 | location 1999-1999 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:17:51

==========

- Your Highlight on page 144 | location 2000-2000 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:17:58

==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 144 | location 2007-2008 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 09:18:29

For example, aerobic exercise tends to increase a person’s metabolic rate and energy level. So if you use exercise to help you cope with anxiety, you’ll
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 145 | location 2016-2018 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 15:58:45

Furthermore, exercise is helpful for people who are sensitive to the symptoms of anxiety, such as increased heart rate or breathlessness, because those sensations are also associated with exercise. Therefore, exercise can serve as a form of exposure that decreases people’s discomfort about those sensations (Broman-Fulks and Storey 2008).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 145 | location 2021-2022 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 15:59:06

In other words, you may be able to achieve a tranquilizing effect without taking tranquilizers.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 146 | location 2034-2036 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 15:59:59

exhilaration (Anderson and Shivakumar 2013). “Endorphin” is a shortened name for “endogenous morphine,” meaning “morphine-like substances produced naturally in the body.” And as that suggests, these compounds can reduce pain and produce a sense of well-being through their effects on the brain.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 146 | location 2041-2045 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 16:00:51

Additional research involving rats running on their wheels has shown that exercise changes the chemistry of the amygdala, including altered levels of the neurotransmitters norepinephrine (Dunn et al. 1996) and serotonin (Bequet et al. 2001). Exercise appears to affect a certain type of serotonin receptor that’s found in large numbers in the lateral nucleus of the amygdala (Greenwood et al. 2012). Regular exercise seems to make these receptors less active, resulting in a calmer amygdala that’s less likely to create an anxiety response (Heisler et al. 2007).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 147 | location 2045-2046 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 16:08:41

This calming effect on the amygdala after regular exercise has been found in humans (Broocks et al. 2001), as well as in mice and rats.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 147 | location 2051-2052 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:12:07

Scientists have learned that simply exercising can increase levels of neurotransmitters and promote the
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 147 | location 2057-2059 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:13:05

Greater left frontal activation has been associated with a more positive mood, suggesting that exercise can stimulate the cortex in a manner that produces more positive feelings. Those positive feelings are likely to help reduce anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 149 | location 2077-2078 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:22:48

By promoting activation of the SNS, the amygdala can keep you in an alert state that prevents you from cycling down into deep sleep.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 149 | location 2079-2081 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:23:00

Worse, if you don’t take steps to ensure that you get good sleep, you run the risk of making your anxiety even worse, since a lack of sleep can make the amygdala prone to more anxious responding.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 152 | location 2112-2113 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:28:19

Researchers have found that lower reactivity in the amygdala is associated with getting more REM sleep (van der Helm et al. 2011).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 152 | location 2117-2119 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:28:45

When you return to sleep after being awake for even just half an hour, the sleep cycles start over from the beginning, so it will take many more hours to get through an entire sleep period. It isn’t like returning to watching a movie where you left off. It’s like having to go through the whole movie again from the beginning.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 157 | location 2153-2155 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:30:58

Many people are familiar with the idea of using thoughts to control anxiety, having learned about this approach either from therapists or by reading about how thoughts, or cognitions, contribute to creating anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 157 | location 2157-2159 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:31:23

Our goal is not to explain every cortex-based approach in detail, but to show you how these strategies contribute to the process of rewiring your cortex to ease anxiety in lasting ways. As mentioned in the introduction,
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 157 | location 2159-2160 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:31:34

“cognition” is the psychological term for cortex processes that most people refer to as “thinking.”
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 158 | location 2162-2163 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:31:48

For example, you may overemphasize the dangerousness of a situation, such as fearing a plane crash despite the overall safety of air travel.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 158 | location 2163-2164 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:32:16

Or you may interpret someone else’s behavior as being personally relevant when it has nothing to do with you, such as assuming that someone is talking during your presentation because you’re boring.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 158 | location 2164-2166 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:32:23

Cognitions can cause us to anticipate problems that will never occur or worry about bodily sensations that are quite harmless.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 158 | location 2168-2169 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:32:40

Cognitive therapists focus on identifying and changing thoughts that are self-defeating or dysfunctional, particularly thoughts that lead to increased levels of anxiety or depression. This approach is known as cognitive restructuring.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 158 | location 2171-2173 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:32:59

Our thoughts are not simply a result of neurological and chemical processes in the brain; they are the neurological and chemical processes in the brain. In cognitive restructuring, the thoughts you think are used to rewire your brain.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 159 | location 2176-2177 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:34:34

It’s crucial to have a clear understanding of the ways in which thoughts can affect the amygdala’s reactions and the ways in which their impact is limited.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 159 | location 2177-2178 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:34:43

Because anxiety can occur automatically, without input from the cortex’s cognitive processing, changing thoughts can’t always prevent anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 159 | location 2183-2184 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:35:30

When people change their thoughts, they may be able to prevent cortex-based processes from contributing to their anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 159 | location 2185-2186 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:35:57

But, rather than adding fuel to the fire, you can learn to control what you’re imagining, thinking, or telling yourself and remain more even keeled.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 159 | location 2186-2187 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:36:02

As difficult as it may seem to change thoughts and thought processes, it’s easier than coping with the emotional reactions created by the amygdala in response to anxiety-provoking thoughts.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2192-2193 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:36:51

When you experience a situation or event, the situation or event itself doesn’t cause you to have an emotion.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2193-2194 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:37:06

Despite the fact that people frequently say things like “My husband makes me so mad,” it isn’t their spouse that causes the emotional reaction. The cortex’s interpretation of the situation is what leads to the emotional reaction.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2195-2197 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:37:26

If you doubt this, consider that different people have different emotional reactions to the same event. Therefore, the event can’t be the cause of the emotion.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2198-2199 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:39:59

Monique, on the other hand, isn’t too concerned and simply wants to enjoy her time with Jayden, whom she hasn’t seen in weeks. The event is the same for both women: Josh doesn’t show up. But their interpretations are obviously quite different.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2201-2201 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:40:21

This is an opportunity to spend time alone with my friend Jayden.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 160 | location 2202-2203 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:40:30

Note that each of these interpretations will lead to a different feeling, demonstrating that it is the interpretation, not the situation itself, that causes the specific feeling.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 161 | location 2210-2212 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:41:30

It can take some work to think through the situation and identify the way you want to interpret it. Also, you may not always want to alter your emotional reactions; sometimes they may be appropriate or useful. However, having the ability to alter your cortex’s interpretations can often go a long way toward reducing your anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 162 | location 2224-2225 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:42:22

My teacher is giving me helpful feedback. I’m going to learn how to be a better writer and I can get a better grade. Clearly, these interpretations of the same event won’t create the same level of anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 162 | location 2226-2226 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:42:37

The situations in which you feel anxiety can provide opportunities for you to examine the interpretations your cortex is providing.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 162 | location 2226-2227 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:42:45

The situations in which you feel anxiety can provide opportunities for you to examine the interpretations your cortex is providing. Keep the three elements in mind: event, interpretation, and resulting emotion.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 163 | location 2251-2252 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:43:26

We call all of the cortex-based tendencies below anxiety-igniting thoughts because they have the potential to activate the amygdala. In fact, they could be a primary source of your anxiety.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 163 | location 2256-2258 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:43:44

Some people tend to be optimistic and expect the best, while others are more pessimistic and expect the worst. Optimism is more common, and it tends to result in less anxiety. If you tend to be pessimistic, you’re likely to be more anxious. Furthermore, a pessimistic attitude can make you less willing to try to change your anxiety because you don’t expect success.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 164 | location 2268-2270 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:44:19

Optimism is more associated with left hemisphere activation, whereas pessimism is associated with the right hemisphere (Hecht 2013). The right hemisphere is more focused on identifying threats and what can go wrong, so increased activation in the right hemisphere is associated with
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2271-2272 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:44:26

situation has been shown to activate the left hemisphere (McRae et al. 2012), which is evidence that a pessimistic attitude can be modified.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2272-2275 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:44:49

The nucleus accumbens, a structure in the frontal lobes, also plays a role in this. The nucleus accumbens is a pleasure center in the brain that’s involved in hope, optimism, and the anticipation of rewards. It’s where the neurotransmitter dopamine is released, and studies have shown that when brain levels of dopamine are higher, negative expectations are reduced and optimism increases (Sharot et al. 2012).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2275-2279 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:45:09

Neuroscientist Richard Davidson has found that the more activity there is in a person’s nucleus accumbens, the more positive outlook the person has (Davidson and Begley 2012). Davidson maintains that this part of the brain underlies optimistic approaches to life, and some researchers have indeed found that the nucleus accumbens reacts differently in pessimists than in optimists (Leknes et al. 2011). Other researchers have found that optimists are more likely to have more activation in the anterior cingulate cortex, a brain structure in the frontal lobe (Sharot 2011).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2280-2281 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:45:49

People who are optimistic tend to be happier, handle adversity better, and have better health (Peters et al. 2010).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2281-2283 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:45:57

They are more motivated to try to do things and, when they fail, to try again, since they expect something good to come of their efforts (Sharot 2011). They tend to worry less and to focus on positive results, whether or not their expectations are valid.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2284-2286 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:46:11

life. Focusing on the negative simply isn’t an emotionally rewarding way to live. If pessimism is a factor for you, you’ll benefit from the cortex-based interventions discussed in chapter 11, including thought-stopping, cognitive restructuring,
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 165 | location 2286-2286 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:46:16

coping statements, and mindfulness.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 167 | location 2302-2303 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 17:46:51

As mentioned, it can involve images or thoughts, and often involves problem-solving thoughts designed to prevent or minimize anticipated future difficulties.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 167 | location 2309-2310 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 18:05:43

It can help us anticipate what will happen so we can meet deadlines, prepare dinner on time, and plan our careers.
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 167 | location 2311-2312 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 18:05:50

Some researchers suggest that worrying is a way of trying to use left hemisphere verbal processing to avoid negative images from the right hemisphere (Compton et al. 2008).
==========
Rewire Your Anxious Brain (How to Use the Neuroscience of Fear to End Anxiety, Panic, and Worry) (Pittman, Catherine M.)
- Your Highlight on page 167 | location 2317-2318 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 18:06:40

The ongoing flow of information back and forth between the frontal cortex and the amygdala, which would allow more flexibility in thinking and responding, gets caught in a loop.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 168 | location 2319-2322 | Added on Saturday, 6 March 2021 18:54:58

This is quite different from effective planning or problem solving. If you have difficulties with worry, <You have reached the clipping limit for this item>

The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 89-89 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:07:31

The less you fear, the more power you will have and the more fully you will live.
==========
The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 101-103 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:09:05

Out of fear, we also developed religion and various belief systems to comfort us. Fear is the oldest and strongest emotion known to man, something deeply inscribed in our nervous system and subconscious.
==========
The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 117-118 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:15:35

We shift from feeling fear because of some threat, to having a fearful attitude towards life itself. We come to see almost every event in terms of risk.
==========
The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 123-124 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:16:50

It seemed to him that people were not only more fearful than necessary but that their fears were making it harder to surmount adversity.

The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 129-131 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:17:25

==========
The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 132-133 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:17:41

- Your Highlight at location 133-134 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:17:54

- Your Highlight at location 147-150 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:22:13

Understand: we are all too afraid—of offending people, of stirring up conflict, of standing out from the crowd, of taking bold action. For thousands of years our relationship to this emotion has evolved—from a primitive fear of nature, to generalized anxiety about the future, to the fearful attitude that now dominates us. As rational, productive adults we are called upon to finally overcome this downward trend and to evolve beyond our fears.
==========
The 50th Law (The Modern Machiavellian Robert Greene) (50 Cent)
- Your Highlight at location 158-161 | Added on Sunday, 7 March 2021 16:23:23

But the racism of the times constricted their ability to give full rein to this spirit.

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 2 | location 79-81 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:37:56

Those new disciplines are neuroscience, the study of how the brain supports mental processes; developmental psychopathology, the study of the impact of adverse experiences on the development of mind and brain; and interpersonal neurobiology, the study of how our behavior influences the emotions, biology, and mind-sets of those around us.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 2 | location 81-83 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:43:32

Research from these new disciplines has revealed that trauma produces actual physiological changes, including a recalibration of the brain’s alarm system, an increase in stress hormone activity, and alterations in the system that filters relevant information from irrelevant.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 3 | location 84-85 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:43:50

- Your Highlight on page 3 | location 86-87 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:44:02

- Your Highlight on page 3 | location 90-93 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:44:42

top down, by talking, (re-) connecting with others, and allowing ourselves to know and understand what is going on with us, while processing the memories of the trauma; 2) by taking medicines that shut down inappropriate alarm reactions, or by utilizing other technologies that change the way the brain organizes information, and 3) bottom up: by allowing the body to have experiences that deeply and viscerally contradict the helplessness, rage, or collapse that result from trauma.

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 3 | location 98-103 | Added on Tuesday, 6 July 2021 19:45:51

Our principal mission has always been to take care of the children and adults who have come to us for treatment, but from the very beginning we also have dedicated ourselves to conducting research to explore the effects of traumatic stress on different populations and to determine what treatments work for whom. We have been supported by research grants from the National Institute of Mental Health, the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control, and a number of private foundations to study the efficacy of many different forms of treatment, from medications to talking, yoga, EMDR, theater, and neurofeedback.

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 30 | location 558-564 | Added on Saturday, 10 July 2021 12:49:29

A group of young researchers, among them Steve Southwick and John Krystal at Yale, Arieh Shalev at Hadassah Medical School in Jerusalem, Frank Putnam at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), and Roger Pitman, later at Harvard, were all finding that traumatized people keep secreting large amounts of stress hormones long after the actual danger has passed, and Rachel Yehuda at Mount Sinai in New York confronted us with her seemingly paradoxical findings that the levels of the stress hormone cortisol are low in PTSD. Her discoveries only started to make sense when her research clarified that cortisol puts an end to the stress response by sending an all-safe signal, and that, in PTSD, the body’s stress hormones do, in fact, not return to baseline after the threat has passed.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 31 | location 585-587 | Added on Saturday, 10 July 2021 12:54:00

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 33 | location 626-628 | Added on Saturday, 10 July 2021 13:26:40

Animals with low serotonin levels were hyperreactive to stressful stimuli (like loud sounds), while higher levels of serotonin dampened their fear system, making them less likely to become aggressive or frozen in response to potential threats.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 37 | location 694-695 | Added on Saturday, 10 July 2021 23:52:28

- Your Highlight on page 42 | location 794-796 | Added on Monday, 12 July 2021 21:59:35

- Your Highlight on page 44 | location 836-837 | Added on Monday, 12 July 2021 22:33:30

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 53 | location 917-919 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:46:08

Being traumatized means continuing to organize your life as if the trauma were still going on—unchanged and immutable—as every new encounter or event is contaminated by the past.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 53 | location 919-920 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:46:21

- Your Highlight on page 53 | location 921-922 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:46:38

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 54 | location 930-931 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:48:06

If the fight/flight/freeze response is successful and we escape the danger, we recover our internal equilibrium and gradually “regain our senses.”
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 54 | location 934-935 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:48:21

Long after the actual event has passed, the brain may keep sending signals to the body to escape a threat that no longer exists.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 54 | location 935-939 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:48:52

Since at least 1889, when the French psychologist Pierre Janet published the first scientific account of traumatic stress,3 it has been recognized that trauma survivors are prone to “continue the action, or rather the (futile) attempt at action, which began when the thing happened.” Being able to move and do something to protect oneself is a critical factor in determining whether or not a horrible experience will leave long-lasting scars.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 944-948 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:50:05

stimulating ongoing fear, depression, rage, and physical disease. In this chapter I’m going to go deeper into the brain’s response to trauma. The more neuroscience discovers about the brain, the more we realize that it is a vast network of interconnected parts organized to help us survive and flourish. Knowing how these parts work together is essential to understanding how trauma affects every part of the human organism and can serve as an indispensable guide to resolving traumatic stress.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 949-952 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:50:37

generate internal signals that register what our bodies need, such as food, rest, protection, sex, and shelter; (2) create a map of the world to point us where to go to satisfy those needs; (3) generate the necessary energy and actions to get us there; (4) warn us of dangers and opportunities along the way; and (5) adjust our actions based on the requirements of the moment.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 953-955 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:50:55

Psychological problems occur when our internal signals don’t work, when our maps don’t lead us where we need to go, when we are too paralyzed to move, when our actions do not correspond
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 953-955 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:50:58

Psychological problems occur when our internal signals don’t work, when our maps don’t lead us where we need to go, when we are too paralyzed to move, when our actions do not correspond to our needs, or when our relationships break down.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 955-956 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:51:19

Every brain structure that I discuss has a role to play in these essential functions, and as we will see, trauma can interfere with every one of them.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 957-959 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:51:39

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 55 | location 959-961 | Added on Monday, 2 August 2021 21:51:56

and to some degree separate, brains, which are in charge of everything else: the moment-by-moment registration and management of our body’s physiology and the identification of comfort, safety, threat, hunger, fatigue, desire, longing, excitement, pleasure, and pain.

The most primitive part, the part that is already online when we are born, is the ancient animal brain, often called the reptilian brain. It is located in the brain stem, just above the place where our spinal cord enters the skull. The reptilian brain is responsible for all the things that newborn babies can do: eat, sleep, wake, cry, breathe; feel temperature, hunger, wetness, and pain; and rid the body of toxins by urinating and defecating. The
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 56 | location 971-972 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:32:14

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 56 | location 974-976 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:34:42

It is the seat of the emotions, the monitor of danger, the judge of what is pleasurable or scary, the arbiter of what is or is not important for survival purposes. It is also a central command post for coping with the challenges of living within our complex social networks.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 56 | location 977-978 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:35:44

(As all parents of more than one child quickly notice, babies differ from birth in the intensity and nature of their reactions to similar events.)
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 56 | location 981-982 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:36:37

If you feel safe and loved, your brain becomes specialized in exploration, play, and cooperation; if you are frightened and unwanted, it specializes in managing
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 56 | location 981-983 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:36:40

If you feel safe and loved, your brain becomes specialized in exploration, play, and cooperation; if you are frightened and unwanted, it specializes in managing feelings of fear and abandonment.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 57 | location 986-988 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:38:22

These early explorations shape the limbic structures devoted to emotions and memory, but these structures can also be significantly modified by later experiences: for the better by a close friendship or a beautiful first love, for example, or for the worse by a violent assault, relentless bullying, or neglect.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 57 | location 990-991 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:38:46

it detects danger or a special opportunity—such as a promising partner—it alerts you by releasing a squirt of hormones. The resulting visceral sensations (ranging from
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 57 | location 994-998 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:39:36

befriend and whom we detest. The emotional brain’s cellular organization and biochemistry are simpler than those of the neocortex, our rational brain, and it assesses incoming information in a more global way. As a result, it jumps to conclusions based on rough similarities, in contrast with the rational brain, which is organized to sort through a complex set of options. (The textbook example is leaping back in terror when you see a snake—only to realize that it’s just a coiled rope.)
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 58 | location 1009-1009 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:41:17

The frontal lobes allow us to plan and reflect, to imagine and play out future scenarios.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 58 | location 1010-1011 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:41:24

They make choice possible and underlie our astonishing creativity.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 58 | location 1011-1012 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:41:29

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 1046-1048 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:52:39

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 1048-1050 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:52:49

The neuroscientist Joseph LeDoux calls the pathway to the amygdala “the low road,” which is extremely fast, and that to the frontal cortex the “high road,” which takes several milliseconds longer in the midst of an overwhelmingly threatening experience.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 1051-1052 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:56:34

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 1055-1056 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:56:56

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 60 | location 1056-1058 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 21:57:13

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)

==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 63 | location 1098-1101 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 22:11:28

Effectively dealing with stress depends upon achieving a balance between the smoke detector and the watchtower. If you want to manage your emotions better, your brain gives you two options: You can learn to regulate them from the top down or from the bottom up. Knowing the difference between top down and bottom up regulation is central for understanding and treating traumatic stress.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 63 | location 1101-1105 | Added on Tuesday, 3 August 2021 22:11:42

Top-down regulation involves strengthening the capacity of the watchtower to monitor your body’s sensations. Mindfulness meditation and yoga can help with this. Bottom-up regulation involves recalibrating the autonomic nervous system, (which, as we have seen, originates in the brain stem). We can access the ANS through breath, movement, or touch. Breathing is one of the few body functions under both conscious and autonomic control. In part 5 of this book we’ll explore specific techniques for increasing both top-down and bottom-up regulation.
==========

We instinctively read the dynamic between two people simply from their tension or relaxation, their postures and tone of voice, their changing facial expressions. Watch
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 75 | location 1290-1292 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:04:07

We instinctively read the dynamic between two people simply from their tension or relaxation, their postures and tone of voice, their changing facial expressions. Watch a movie in a language you don’t know, and you can still guess the quality of the relationship between the characters.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 75 | location 1295-1299 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:04:34

Behaviors to avoid or escape from danger have clearly evolved to render each organism competitive in terms of survival. But inappropriately prolonged escape or avoidance behavior would put the animal at a disadvantage in that successful species preservation demands reproduction which, in turn, depends upon feeding, shelter and mating activities all of which are reciprocals of avoidance and escape.3
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1299-1300 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:04:56

In other words: If an organism is stuck in survival mode, its energies are focused on fighting off unseen enemies, which leaves no room for nurture, care, and love. For
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1299-1301 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:05:50

In other words: If an organism is stuck in survival mode, its energies are focused on fighting off unseen enemies, which leaves no room for nurture, care, and love. For us humans, it means that as long as the mind is defending itself against invisible assaults, our closest bonds are threatened, along with our ability to imagine, plan, play,
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1299-1302 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:05:53

In other words: If an organism is stuck in survival mode, its energies are focused on fighting off unseen enemies, which leaves no room for nurture, care, and love. For us humans, it means that as long as the mind is defending itself against invisible assaults, our closest bonds are threatened, along with our ability to imagine, plan, play, learn, and pay attention to other people’s needs.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1304-1306 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:08:15

When the mind is strongly excited, it instantly affects the state of the viscera; so that under excitement there will be much mutual action and reaction between these, the two most important organs of the body.”4
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1307-1309 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:08:28

As long as we register emotions primarily in our heads, we can remain pretty much in control, but feeling as if our chest is caving in or we’ve been punched in the gut is unbearable.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1309-1311 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:08:39

We’ll do anything to make these awful visceral sensations go away, whether it is clinging desperately to another human being, rendering ourselves insensible with drugs or alcohol, or taking a knife to the skin to replace overwhelming emotions with definable sensations.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1311-1312 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:08:51

How many mental health problems, from drug addiction to self-injurious behavior, start as attempts to cope with the unbearable physical pain of our emotions? If Darwin was right, the solution requires finding ways to help people
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 76 | location 1311-1313 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:08:54

How many mental health problems, from drug addiction to self-injurious behavior, start as attempts to cope with the unbearable physical pain of our emotions? If Darwin was right, the solution requires finding ways to help people alter the inner sensory landscape of their bodies.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1318-1320 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:09:42

All are a product of the synchrony between the two branches of the autonomic nervous system (ANS): the sympathetic, which acts as the body’s accelerator, and the parasympathetic, which serves as its brake.6
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1322-1324 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:09:57

The sympathetic nervous system (SNS) is responsible for arousal, including the fight-or-flight response (Darwin’s “escape or avoidance behavior”). Almost two thousand years ago the Roman physician Galen gave it the name “sympathetic” because he observed that it functioned with the emotions (sym pathos).
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1326-1328 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:10:16

parasympathetic (“against emotions”) nervous system (PNS), which promotes self-preservative functions like digestion and wound healing. It triggers the release of acetylcholine to put a brake on arousal, slowing the heart down, relaxing muscles, and returning breathing to normal. As Darwin pointed out, “feeding,
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1326-1329 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:10:19

parasympathetic (“against emotions”) nervous system (PNS), which promotes self-preservative functions like digestion and wound healing. It triggers the release of acetylcholine to put a brake on arousal, slowing the heart down, relaxing muscles, and returning breathing to normal. As Darwin pointed out, “feeding, shelter, and mating activities” depend on the PNS.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1331-1332 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:10:38

Exhaling, in turn, activates the PNS, which slows down the heart. If you take a yoga or a meditation class, your instructor will probably urge you to pay particular attention to the exhalation, since deep, long breaths out help calm you down.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 77 | location 1333-1336 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:11:26

A measurement called heart rate variability (HRV) can be used to test the flexibility of this system, and good HRV—the more fluctuation, the better—is a sign that the brake and accelerator in your arousal system are both functioning properly and in balance. We had a breakthrough when we acquired an instrument to measure HRV, and I will explain in chapter 16 how we can use HRV to help treat PTSD.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1345-1346 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:13:53

helped us understand why focused attunement with another person can shift us out of disorganized and fearful states.8
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1346-1347 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:13:58

short, Porges’s theory made us look beyond the effects of fight or flight and put social relationships front and center in our understanding of trauma.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1348-1353 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:14:38

Human beings are astoundingly attuned to subtle emotional shifts in the people (and animals) around them. Slight changes in the tension of the brow, wrinkles around the eyes, curvature of the lips, and angle of the neck quickly signal to us how comfortable, suspicious, relaxed, or frightened someone is.9 Our mirror neurons register their inner experience, and our own bodies make internal adjustments to whatever we notice. Just so, the muscles of our own faces give others clues about how calm or excited we feel, whether our heart is racing or quiet, and whether
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1353-1355 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:14:41

we’re ready to pounce on them or run away. When the message we receive from another person is “You’re safe with me,” we relax. If we’re lucky in our relationships, we also feel nourished, supported, and restored as we look into the face and eyes of the other.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 78 | location 1355-1356 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:16:21

Our culture teaches us to focus on personal uniqueness, but at a deeper level we barely exist as individual organisms. Our brains are built to help us function as members of a tribe.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1361-1362 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:17:46

both. The standard medical focus on trying to discover the right drug to treat a particular “disorder” tends to distract us from grappling with how our problems interfere
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1362-1363 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:17:49

with our functioning as members of our tribe.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1363-1366 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:17:58

A few years ago I heard Jerome Kagan, a distinguished emeritus professor of child psychology at Harvard, say to the Dalai Lama that for every act of cruelty in this world there are hundreds of small acts of kindness and connection. His conclusion: “To be benevolent rather than malevolent is probably a true feature of our species.”
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1366-1368 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:18:15

Being able to feel safe with other people is probably the single most important aspect of mental health; safe connections are fundamental to meaningful and satisfying lives. Numerous studies of disaster response around the globe have shown that social support is the most powerful protection against becoming overwhelmed by stress and trauma.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1369-1370 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:18:29

The critical issue is reciprocity: being truly heard and seen by the people around us, feeling that we are held in someone else’s mind and heart. For
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1371-1372 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:18:42

You don’t need a history of trauma to feel self-conscious and even panicked at a party with strangers—but trauma
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1372-1372 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:18:45

can turn the whole world into a gathering of aliens.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1373-1376 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:19:51

Some find comfort in groups where they can replay their combat experiences, rape, or torture with others who have similar backgrounds or experiences. Focusing on a shared history of trauma and victimization alleviates their searing sense of isolation, but usually at the price of having to deny their individual differences: Members can belong only if they conform to the common code.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1376-1377 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:20:06

Isolating oneself into a narrowly defined victim group promotes a view of others as irrelevant at best and dangerous at worst, which eventually only leads to further alienation.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 79 | location 1379-1380 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:20:25

functioning people are able to accept individual differences and acknowledge the humanity of others.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1380-1381 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:20:34

In the past two decades it has become widely recognized that when adults or children are too skittish or shut down to derive comfort from human beings, relationships with other mammals can help.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1381-1383 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:20:41

Dogs and horses and even dolphins offer less complicated companionship while providing the necessary sense of safety. Dogs and horses, in particular, are now extensively used to treat some groups of trauma patients.10
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1385-1386 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:22:31

When we try to help people with faulty neuroception, the great challenge is finding ways to reset their physiology, so that their survival mechanisms stop working against them.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1386-1388 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:22:37

This means helping them to respond appropriately to danger but, even more, to recover the capacity to experience safety, relaxation, and true reciprocity.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1391-1393 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:22:57

In the previous chapter we saw the radically different reactions of Stan and Ute as they relived the highway disaster they’d experienced side by side. What accounts for this spectrum of responses: focused, collapsed, or frantic?
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1394-1394 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:23:12

Whenever we feel threatened, we
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1394-1395 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:23:15

Whenever we feel threatened, we instinctively turn to the first level, social engagement.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 80 | location 1396-1399 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:23:28

We fight off our attacker, or we run to a safe place. However, if this fails—we can’t get away, we’re held down or trapped—the organism tries to preserve itself by shutting down and expending as little energy as possible. We are then in a state of freeze or collapse.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 81 | location 1404-1404 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:24:26

As a result, we feel calm and relaxed, centered, or pleasurably aroused.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1411-1413 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:25:26

Any threat to our safety or social connections triggers changes in the areas innervated by the VVC. When something distressing happens, we automatically signal our upset in our facial expressions and tone of voice, changes meant to beckon others to come to our assistance.11
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1414-1415 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:25:33

The sympathetic nervous system takes over, mobilizing muscles, heart, and lungs for fight or flight.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1417-1418 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:26:53

Finally, if there’s no way out, and there’s nothing we can do to stave off the inevitable, we will activate the ultimate emergency system: the dorsal vagal complex (DVC).
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1419-1421 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:27:05

Heart rate plunges (we feel our heart “drop”), we can’t breathe, and our gut stops working or empties (literally “scaring the shit out of” us). This is the point at which we disengage, collapse, and freeze.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1421-1422 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:27:50

we saw in Stan’s and Ute’s brain scans, trauma is expressed not only as fight or flight but also as shutting down and failing to engage in the present.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 82 | location 1421-1424 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:27:58

we saw in Stan’s and Ute’s brain scans, trauma is expressed not only as fight or flight but also as shutting down and failing to engage in the present. A different level of brain activity is involved for each response: the mammalian fight-or-flight system, which is protective and keeps us from shutting down, and the reptilian brain, which produces the collapse response.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1425-1427 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:28:13

In contrast, the snakes and lizards lie motionless in the corners of their cages, unresponsive to the environment.13
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1428-1430 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:28:42

Almost everyone knows what that quintessential fight/flight response, road rage, feels like: A sudden threat precipitates an intense impulse to move and attack. Danger turns off our social-engagement system, decreases our responsiveness to the human voice, and increases our sensitivity to threatening sounds. Yet
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1428-1433 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:28:50

Almost everyone knows what that quintessential fight/flight response, road rage, feels like: A sudden threat precipitates an intense impulse to move and attack. Danger turns off our social-engagement system, decreases our responsiveness to the human voice, and increases our sensitivity to threatening sounds. Yet for many people panic and rage are preferable to the opposite: shutting down and becoming dead to the world. Activating flight/flight at least makes them feel energized. That is why so many abused and traumatized people feel fully alive in the face of actual danger, while they go numb in situations that are more complex but objectively safe, like birthday parties or family dinners. When fighting or
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1433-1434 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:29:06

running does not take care of the threat, we activate the last resort—the reptilian brain, the ultimate emergency system.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1435-1437 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:29:17

Collapse and disengagement are controlled by the DVC, an evolutionarily ancient part of the parasympathetic nervous system that is associated with digestive symptoms like diarrhea and nausea.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1437-1438 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:29:32

this system takes over, other people, and we ourselves, cease to matter. Awareness is shut down, and we may no longer even register physical pain.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1441-1442 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:29:50

The more efficiently the VVC synchronizes the activity of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, the better the physiology of each individual will be attuned to that of other members of the tribe.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 83 | location 1443-1444 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:30:37

Newborn babies are not very social; they sleep most of the time and wake up when they’re hungry or wet.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1445-1446 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:31:16

Early in life they are pretty much at the mercy of the alternating tides of their sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, and their reptilian brain runs most of the show.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1448-1451 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:31:30

The VVC controls sucking, swallowing, facial expression, and the sounds produced by the larynx. When these functions are stimulated in an infant, they are accompanied by a sense of pleasure and safety, which helps create the foundation for all future social behavior.14 As my friend Ed Tronick taught me a long time ago, the brain is a cultural organ—experience shapes the brain. Being in tune with other
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1448-1452 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:31:39

The VVC controls sucking, swallowing, facial expression, and the sounds produced by the larynx. When these functions are stimulated in an infant, they are accompanied by a sense of pleasure and safety, which helps create the foundation for all future social behavior.14 As my friend Ed Tronick taught me a long time ago, the brain is a cultural organ—experience shapes the brain. Being in tune with other members of our species via the VVC is enormously rewarding.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1452-1454 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:31:48

What begins as the attuned play of mother and child continues with the rhythmicity of a good basketball game, the synchrony of tango dancing, and the harmony of choral singing or playing a piece of jazz or chamber music—all of which foster a deep sense of pleasure and connection.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1456-1457 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:32:10

Immobilization is at the root of most traumas. When that occurs the DVC is likely to take over: Your heart slows down, your breathing becomes shallow,
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1458-1458 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:32:16

and, zombielike, you lose touch with yourself and your surroundings. You dissociate, faint and collapse.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 84 | location 1461-1463 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:32:38

Many traumatized individuals are too hypervigilant to enjoy the ordinary pleasures that life has to offer, while others are too numb to absorb new experiences—or to be alert to signs of real danger.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1465-1467 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:32:52

Women who, as children, had witnessed their mothers being assaulted by their partners had a vastly increased chance to fall victim to domestic violence.15
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1471-1472 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:34:18

This requires having experiences that can restore the sense of physical safety, a topic to which we’ll return many times in the chapters that follow.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1473-1474 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:34:30

get stuck in fight/flight or in chronic shut-down, how do we help them to deactivate these defensive maneuvers that once ensured their survival?
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1477-1479 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:34:49

As Steve leaned over to pick it up, he’d nudge it gently toward the kid, who’d usually give a half hearted push in return. Gradually Steve got a back-and-forth going, and before long you’d see smiles on both faces.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1479-1482 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:35:03

From simple, rhythmically attuned movements, Steve had created a small, safe place where the social-engagement system could begin to reemerge. In the same way, severely traumatized people may get more out of simply helping to arrange chairs before a meeting or joining others in tapping out a musical rhythm on the chair seats than they would from sitting in those same chairs and discussing the failures in their life.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 85 | location 1482-1485 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:35:16

One thing is certain: Yelling at someone who is already out of control can only lead to further dysregulation. Just as your dog cowers if you shout and wags his tail when you speak in a high singsong, we humans respond to harsh voices with fear, anger, or shutdown and to playful tones by opening up and relaxing. We simply cannot help but respond to these indicators of safety or danger.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1486-1488 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:35:31

Despite the well-documented effects of anger, fear, and anxiety on the ability to reason, many programs continue to ignore the need to engage the safety system of the brain before trying to promote new ways of thinking.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1488-1489 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:35:46

The last things that should be cut from school schedules are chorus, physical education, recess, and anything else involving movement, play, and joyful engagement. When
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1489-1491 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:35:57

defensive, numbed out, or enraged, it’s also important to recognize that such “bad behavior” may repeat action patterns that were established to survive serious threats, even if they are intensely upsetting or off-putting.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Bookmark on page 86 | location 1489 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 08:36:03


==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1491-1494 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 19:44:19

Porges’s work has had a profound effect on how my Trauma Center colleagues and I organize the treatment of abused children and traumatized adults. It’s true that we would probably have developed a therapeutic yoga program for women at some point, given that yoga had proved so successful in helping them calm down and get in touch with their dissociated bodies.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1496-1498 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 19:45:34

But the polyvagal theory helped us understand and explain why all these disparate, unconventional techniques worked so well. It enabled us to become more conscious of combining top-down approaches (to activate social engagement) with bottom-up methods (to calm the physical tensions in the body).
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1500-1502 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 19:45:52

All rely on interpersonal rhythms, visceral awareness, and vocal and facial communication, which help shift people out of fight/flight states, reorganize their perception of danger, and increase their capacity to manage relationships.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 86 | location 1502-1505 | Added on Monday, 9 August 2021 19:46:03

The body keeps the score:17 If the memory of trauma is encoded in the viscera, in heartbreaking and gut-wrenching emotions, in autoimmune disorders and skeletal/muscular problems, and if mind/brain/visceral communication is the royal road to emotion regulation, this demands a radical shift in our therapeutic assumptions.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 87 | location 1518-1519 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:18:28

Over the years our research team has repeatedly found that chronic emotional abuse and neglect can be just as devastating as physical abuse and sexual molestation.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1520-1522 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:18:42

Not being seen, not being known, and having nowhere to turn to feel safe is devastating at any age, but it is particularly destructive for young children, who are still trying to find their place in the world.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1527-1527 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:19:24

Sherry told me that she’d started to pick at her skin because it gave her some relief from feeling numb.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1529-1531 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:19:42

She’d also been subjected to involuntary hospitalization by a psychiatrist who refused to treat her unless she could promise that she would never pick at herself again.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1532-1534 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:20:03

As I discussed in the previous chapter, the most common response to distress is to seek out people we like and trust to help us and give us the courage to go on. We
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1534-1534 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:20:10

may also calm down by engaging in a physical activity like biking or going to the gym.
==========
The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 88 | location 1536-1539 | Added on Tuesday, 10 August 2021 07:20:33

But if no one has ever looked at you with loving eyes or broken out in a smile when she sees you; if no one has rushed to help you (but instead said, “Stop crying, or I’ll give you something to cry about”), then you need to discover other ways of taking care of yourself. You are likely to experiment with anything—drugs, alcohol, binge eating, or cutting—that offers some kind of relief.
==========

Like a veil thrown over the skin to secure its modesty, the screen partially removes from the mind the inner states of the body, those that constitute the flow of life as it wanders in the journey of each day.”6 He goes on to describe how this “screen” can work in our favor by enabling us to attend to pressing problems in the outside world. Yet it has a cost: “It tends to prevent us from sensing the possible origin and nature of what we call self.”7 Building on the century-old work of William James, Damasio argues that the core of our self-awareness rests on the physical sensations that convey the inner states of the body:

The Body Keeps the Score (Kolk, Bessel van der)
- Your Highlight on page 95 | location 1654-1659 | Added on Wednesday, 11 August 2021 18:10:23

For example, a particular part of the brain stem was “active in sadness and anger, but not in happiness or fear.”10 All of these brain regions are below the limbic system, to which emotions are traditionally assigned, yet we acknowledge their involvement every time we use one of the common expressions that link strong emotions with the body: “You make me sick”; “It made my skin crawl”; “I was all choked up”; “My heart sank”; “He makes me bristle.”

- Your Highlight on page 102 | location 1809-1812 | Added on Sunday, 15 August 2021 16:51:52

They just reacted with intense activation deep inside their emotional brains, in the primitive areas known as the Periaqueductal Gray, which generates startle, hypervigilance, cowering, and other self-protective behaviors. There was no activation of any part of the brain involved in social engagement. In response to being looked at they simply went into survival mode.
